name: Vietnamese Crispy Salt and Pepper Shrimp (Tôm Rang Muối)
description: Bite-sized bursts of savory, salty, and spicy (optional) flavors, these crispy fried shrimp are the perfect easy-to-make appetizer for any occasion.
keywords: tôm chiên muối tiêu, tôm rang muối tiêu, tôm chiên, tôm rang, tom chien, tom rang, tom chien muoi, tom chien muoi tieu, tom rang muoi, tom rang muoi tieu, crispy salt and pepper shrimp, Vietnamese salt and pepper shrimp, Vietnamese salt and pepper shrimp recipe, crispy salt and pepper shrimp recipe, crispy shrimp recipe, shrimp recipe, Asian shrimp recipe, Vietnamese shrimp recipe, fry shrimp recipe, Vietnamese fried shrimp recipe, salt and pepper shrimp, fried salt and pepper shrimp, how to make salt and pepper shrimp, what is salt and pepper shrimp made of, Vietnamese spice mixture for fried shrimp, Vietnamese spice mixture for fried protein, Vietnamese spice mixture for fried food, salt and pepper shrimp, easy salt and pepper shrimp recipe, easy salt and pepper shrimp
recipeIngredient: 2 lbs whole shrimp (about 25-30 21/25 size large devein shrimp; head tail optional)
2 fresh or dried red chili peppers (see notes)
recipeInstructions: Prep the shrimp: If preferred, cut off the whiskers, sharp point on the head and trim off the eyes with a pair of kitchen shears. I prefer to keep it all intact because they do fry up nicely. Devein the shrimp by inserting a toothpick underneath the vein on the back of the prawn. Slowly pull the toothpick up to remove the vein. Rinse off the shrimp to remove any lingering fishy smell and veins. Set aside.

Prepare the salt mixture: In a small pan, dry toast the salt on medium-low heat until it starts to turn color (about 2 minutes). Turn off heat and transfer the roasted salt to a small bowl. Mix in the ground black pepper and sugar until well combined. Set aside.

Deep fry the shrimp: In a wok or pot, heat vegetable oil to 350°F for deep frying. Dredge shrimp in corn starch and tap off excess. Deep fry the shrimp in batches, dropping them in oil one at a time, and cook for about 3 minutes or until golden and crispy. Transfer the shrimp onto a plate lined with paper towels to absorb excess oil.

In a large wok or skillet, add 2 tablespoons of vegetable oil and heat on medium high. Add jalapenos or chili peppers, garlic, and shallots. Sauté until softened and fragrant (about one minute). Add the fried shrimp and sprinkle with the salt-pepper-sugar mixture. Lightly toss until evenly coated. Serve immediately for best results.
